awd_titl_txt: GEO-Scholar: Increasing Undergraduate Participation in the Geosciences
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at the University of South Carolina (USC) will increase the number of students with demonstrated financial need who complete undergraduate geoscience degrees within the School of the Earth, Ocean, and Environment (SEOE). The program will encourage applications from individuals belonging to groups currently underrepresented in the geosciences and from first generation college students.  In addition to conducting outreach activities and providing scholarships, the project will employ evidenced-based program practices that are built upon existing successful programs at USC.  These practices include a summer orientation, mathematics skills improvement, and a common course program. The program will help students to persist in geosciences majors and graduate in a timely manner. Providing scholarships to academically strong STEM students, who may not otherwise be able to afford college, will increase the number of STEM graduates prepared to fill the needs of national, regional, and local industries.

The GEO-Scholar program at the University of South Carolina will increase student exposure to the geosciences by developing an outreach program that results in increased interest, knowledge, and performance from targeted students.  Each year scholarships will be awarded to 6 to 8 academically talented students majoring in the geosciences who demonstrate financial need.  The project will increase recruitment and retention of students majoring in the geosciences by adding new programs and institutionalizing geoscience modifications to programs that currently exist at USC.  The student support services will include an emphasis on improving mathematics skills, participation in a common course during the first year, and a summer orientation program. GEO-Scholars at USC will increase the number of well-prepared and skilled employees in the geosciences by working with faculty and public and private sectors to provide research, internship, and work opportunities that further familiarize participants with career opportunities in the geosciences. Assessment and evaluation will provide insight into the retention benefits of student scholarships, career development activities, and faculty mentoring and advising. Lessons learned and effective practices that emerge from the program evaluation data will be disseminated widely to the STEM education community and help increase widespread understanding of the attributes and practices of successful student scholarship and support programs.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the GeoScholar Program in the School of the Earth, Ocean, and Environment (SEOE) at the University of SC (UofSC) was to increase the exposure to and number of geoscience undergraduate majors (environmental science, geological sciences, and marine science) from low-income, minority, and first-generation college backgrounds. This program established an outreach and scholarship program that included targeted recruitment, development and revision of introductory and required courses, community building through a living and learning community (Green Quad, GQ) financial support, and mentoring. Results include institutionalization of targeted recruitment and outreach activities, institutionalization of a first-year introduction to the environment course, ENVR 101, which specifically targets traditionally under-represented groups in the geosciences, development and institutionalization of a geoscience specific UNIV 101 course that focuses on helping students make a successful transition to campus by fostering a sense of belonging, promoting engagement in university opportunities, etc., and revision of the first-year calculus sequence required by all STEM majors. This project also led to further integration of living and learning communities with targeted geoscience major programming. In 2022, ~ 22% of first year and transfer students in the College of Arts and Sciences at the UofSC identified as a student of color, an increase of ~ 5% since 2016. Note that first year and transfer student enrollments also increased from ~ 1260 to 1800 students, an increase of almost 40%.  While major enrollments in the geosciences remained stagnant, first year and transfer students of color comprised ~ 16% of geoscience majors in Fall 2021 and their graduation rates increased from ~6 to ~13%.  

This grant further supported 23 undergraduate student scholarships. Of the 21 GeoScholars who completed the program, 19 have graduated with their degrees in a geoscience major (two more are still in progress). Seven of the GeoScholars are pursuing postbaccalaureate degrees: Three are currently enrolled in geoscience related master’s degree programs, and three are currently enrolled in doctoral degree programs (two were named NSF GRFP Fellows). One GeoScholar completed a masters in teaching degree with support of a prestigious Noyce Scholarship and is currently teaching middle school science.  Almost all of the other former GeoScholars are currently working in geoscience fields, such as the NOAA Coast Guard, Department of Natural Resources, and the Department of Fish and Wildlife.

GeoScholars highlighted the importance of geoscience specific UNIV 101 courses and emphasized that being in a living and learning community with direct access to supplemental instruction, a resident mentor, and Faculty mentor from the geosciences were critical to their success. Another important finding was that after taking ENVR 101, the self-efficacy of traditionally under-represented students in the geosciences increased substantially, from 3.1 to 4.3 (out of 1 -5 scale). Anecdotal discussion with faculty, staff, and student reviews indicated that ENVR 101 was the one class that all of the students enjoyed and had the highest day to day attendance rate in their program. In summary, this project has improved the performance, skills, and attitudes of members of underrepresented groups in the geosciences and institutionalized development of geoscience professionals with diverse backgrounds and attitudes that will continue to foster innovation in research and technology development.
